BuddhismInMahayanaMahayana Buddhism,bodhisattvais theSanskritterm for anyone who, motivated by great compassion, has generatedbodhicitta, which is a spontaneous wish to attainbuddhahoodfor the benefit of allSentient beings (Buddhism)sentient beings.The Bodhisattva Vow: A Practical Guide to Helping Others, page 1,Tharpa Publications(2nd. ed., 1995) ISBN 978-0-948006-50-0A bodhisattva is one of the four sublime states a human can achieve in life (the others being anarhat,Buddhahoodbuddhaorpratyekabuddha).P. 313Brilliant Moon: The Autobiography of Dilgo Khyentseby Dilgo Khyentse

Usage of the term bodhisattva has evolved over time. In early Indian Buddhism, for example, the termbodhisattvawas primarily used to refer specifically toGautama Buddhain his former lives.cite bookCoomaraswamyAnandaAnanda CoomaraswamyBuddha and the Gospel of Buddhism1975University BooksBoston22564056434"...the term Bodhisatta, or Wisdom-being, first used of [[Gautama Buddha|Gautama]] between the Going-forth and the attainment of [[Nirvana (Buddhism)|Nibbāna]], came to mean a Buddha-designate...."cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/70982/bodhisattvabodhisattva - Buddhist idealEncyclopedia Britannica21 August 2015TheJataka tales, which are the stories of the Buddha's lives, depict the various attempts of the bodhisattva to embrace qualities like self-sacrifice and morality.
Bodhisattvas are a popular subject inBuddhist art.
article.heading: Theravda Buddhism

article.paragraph: InTheravadaTheravada Buddhism, the equivalentPalitermbodhisattais used in thePli Canonto refer to Gautama Buddha in his previous livesBasham, A.L. (1981). The evolution of the concept of the bodhisattva. In: Leslie S Kawamura, The Bodhisattva doctrine in Buddhism, Published for the Canadian Corporation for Studies in Religion by Wilfred Laurier University Press, p.19and as a young man in his current life in the period during which he was working towards his ownmokshaliberation. When, during his discourses, he recounts his experiences as a young aspirant, he regularly uses the phrase "When I was an unenlightened bodhisatta..." The term therefore connotes a being who is "bound for enlightenment", in other words, a person whose aim is to become fully enlightened. In the Pli canon, the bodhisatta is also described as someone who is still subject to birth, illness, death, sorrow, defilement, and delusion. Some of the previous lives of the Buddha as a bodhisattva are featured in the Jataka tales.

In later Theravada literature, the term "bodhisatta" is used fairly frequently in the sense of someone on the path to liberation.The later tradition of commentary also recognizes the existence of two additional types of bodhisattas: thepaccekabodhisatta, who will attainPratyekabuddhaPaccekabuddhahood, and thesavakabodhisatta, who will attain enlightenment as a disciple of a Buddha. According to the Theravda teacherBhikkhu Bodhi, the bodhisattva path was not taught by the Buddha.Cite webhttp://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/bodhi/arahantsbodhisattvas.htmlArahants, Bodhisattvas and Buddhas

Kings ofSri Lankawere often described as bodhisattvas, starting at least as early as Sirisanghabodhi (r. 247-249), who was renowned for his compassion, who took vows for the welfare of the citizens, and was regarded as aMahsattvamahsatta(Sanskritmahsattva), an epithet used almost exclusively in Mahayana Buddhism.Holt, John.Buddha in the Crown : Avalokitesvara in the Buddhist Traditions of Sri Lanka.1991. p. 59Many other kings of Sri Lanka from the 3rd century until the 15th century were also described as bodhisattvas and their royal duties were sometimes clearly associated with the practice of thePramitTen Pramits.Holt, John.Buddha in the Crown : Avalokitesvara in the Buddhist Traditions of Sri Lanka.1991. pp. 59-60

Theravadinbhikkhuand scholarWalpola Rahulastated that the bodhisattva ideal has traditionally been held to be higher than the state of arvakanot only in Mahayana but also in Theravada Buddhism. He also quotes an inscription from the 10th Century king of Sri Lanka,List of Sri Lankan monarchs#House of Lambakanna II .28691.E2.80.931017.29Mahinda IV(956-972 CE), who had the words inscribed "none but the bodhisattvas will become kings of a prosperous Lanka," among other examples.Holt, John.Buddha in the Crown : Avalokitesvara in the Buddhist Traditions of Sri Lanka.1991. p. 60quoteThere is a wide-spread belief, particularly in the West, that the ideal of the Theravada, which they conveniently identify with Hinayana, is to become an Arahant while that of the Mahayana is to become a Bodhisattva and finally to attain the state of a Buddha. It must be categorically stated that this is incorrect. This idea was spread by some early Orientalists at a time when Buddhist studies were beginning in the West, and the others who followed them accepted it without taking the trouble to go into the problem by examining the texts and living traditions in Buddhist countries. But the fact is that both the Theravada and the Mahayana unanimously accept the Bodhisattva ideal as the highest.<arg name="Walpola Rahula, ''Bodhisattva Ideal in Buddhism''{{Cite web|url">http://www.buddhanet.net/budsas/ebud/ebdha126.htm|titlePaul Williams writes that some modern Theravada meditation masters inThailandare popularly regarded as bodhisattvas.quoteCholvijarn observes that prominent figures associated with the [[Dhammakaya Movement|Self perspective]] in Thailand have often been famous outside scholarly circles as well, among the wider populace, as Buddhist meditation masters and sources of miracles and sacred [[amulet]]s. Like perhaps some of the early Mahāyāna forest hermit monks, or the later Buddhist Tantrics, they have become people of power through their meditative achievements. They are widely revered, worshipped, and held to be [[arhat]]s or (note!) bodhisattvas.Paul Williams, ''Mahāyāna Buddhism: The Doctrinal Foundations.'' Taylor & Francis, 1989, page 328.

article.heading: In Mahyna Buddhism
Bodhisattva ideal
article.paragraph: MahayanaMahynaBuddhism is based principally upon the path of a bodhisattva. According to Jan Nattier, the termMahyna("Great Vehicle") was originally even an honorary synonym forBodhisattvayna, or the "Bodhisattva Vehicle."Nattier, Jan (2003),A few good men: the Bodhisattva path according to the Inquiry of Ugra: p. 174TheIASTAṣṭasāhasrikā Prajñāpāramitā Sūtracontains a simple and brief definition for the termbodhisattva, which is also the earliest known Mahyna definition.Mall, Linnart.Studies in the Astasahasrika Prajnaparamita and Other Essays.Motilal Banarsidass. 2005. pp. 53-54.Hirakawa, Akira.A history of Indian Buddhism: from kyamuni to Early Mahyna.Motilal Banarsidass. 2007. p. 297.This definition is given as the following.Conze, Edward.The Perfection of Wisdom in Eight Thousand Lines and its Verse Summary.Grey Fox Press. 2001. p. 89.

template.arg: Because he has enlightenment as his aim, a bodhisattva-[[mahāsattva]] is so called.

article.paragraph: The earliest depiction of the Bodhisattva path in texts such as theUgraparipcch Stradescribe it as an arduous, difficult monastic path suited only for the few which is nevertheless the most glorious path one can take. Three kinds of Bodhisattvas are mentioned in the early Mahayana texts, the forest, city, and monastery Bodhisattvas - with forest dwelling being promoted a superior, even necessary path in sutras such as theSamadhiraja Sutraand theUgraparipcch Stra.Ray, Reginald. Buddhist saints in India, page 252.The early Rastrapalapariprccha sutra also promotes a solitary life of meditation in the forests, far away from the distractions of the householder life. The Rastrapala is also highly critical of monks living in monasteries and in cities who are seen as not practicing meditation and morality.Ray, Reginald. Buddhist saints in India, page 265.The Ratnagunasamcayagatha also says the Bodhisattva should undertake ascetic practices (dhutanga), "wander freely without a home", practice theparamitasand train under a guru in order to perfect his meditation practice and realization ofprajnaparamita.Ray, Reginald. Buddhist saints in India, page 255.These texts seem to indicate the initial Bodhisattva ideal was associated with a strict forestasceticism.

Mahyna Buddhism encourages everyone to become bodhisattvas and to take thebodhisattva vows. With these vows, one makes the promise to work for the complete enlightenment of allSentient beings (Buddhism)sentient beingsby practicing the six perfections.The Bodhisattva Vow: A Practical Guide to Helping Others, pages 4-12,Tharpa Publications(2nd. ed., 1995) ISBN 978-0-948006-50-0Indelibly entwined with the bodhisattva vow isparinamanamerit transference(pariman).

In Mahyna Buddhism life in this world is compared to people living in a house that is on fire. People take this world as reality pursuing worldly projects and pleasures without realizing that the house is on fire and will soon burn down (due to the inevitability of death). A bodhisattva is one who has a determination to free sentient beings fromsamsaraand its cycle of death, rebirth and suffering. This type of mind is known as thebodhicittamind of awakening(bodhicitta). Bodhisattvas takebodhisattva vowsin order to progress on the spiritual path towardsbuddhahood.

There are a variety of different conceptions of the nature of a bodhisattva in Mahyna. According to some Mahyna sources a bodhisattva is someone on the path to full Buddhahood. Others speak of bodhisattvas renouncing Buddhahood. According to theKun-bzang bla-ma'i zhal-lung, a bodhisattva can choose any of three paths to help sentient beings in the process of achieving buddhahood. They are:

list.listitem: king-like bodhisattva - one who aspires to become buddha as soon as possible and then help sentient beings in full fledge;
boatman-like bodhisattva - one who aspires to achieve buddhahood along with other sentient beings;

shepherd-like bodhisattva - one who aspires to delay buddhahood untilall other sentient beings achieve buddhahood. Bodhisattvas likeAvalokiteshvaraAvalokitevaraandShantidevantidevaare believed to fall in this category.

article.paragraph: According to the doctrine of some Tibetan schools (like Theravda but for different reasons), only the first of these is recognized. It is held that Buddhas remain in the world, able to help others, so there is no point in delay.Kelsang GyatsoGeshe Kelsang Gyatsonotes:Geshe Kelsang Gyatso,Joyful Path of Good Fortune: the Complete Buddhist Path to Enlightenment,p. 422In reality, the second two types of bodhicitta are wishes that are impossible to fulfill because it is only possible to lead others to enlightenment once we have attained enlightenment ourself. Therefore, only king-like bodhicitta is actual bodhicitta. Je Tsongkhapa says that although the other Bodhisattvas wish for that which is impossible, their attitude is sublime and unmistaken.

TheNyingmaschool, however, holds that the lowest level is the way of the king, who primarily seeks his own benefit but who recognizes that his benefit depends crucially on that of his kingdom and his subjects. The middle level is the path of the boatman, who ferries his passengers across the river and simultaneously, of course, ferries himself as well. The highest level is that of the shepherd, who makes sure that all his sheep arrive safely ahead of him and places their welfare above his own.Patrul Rinpoche, ''Words of My Perfect Teacher," page 218, "The king's way, called 'arousing bodhicitta with the great wish,' is the least courageous of the three. The boatman's way, called 'arousing bodhicitta with sacred wisdom,' is more courageous. It is said that Lord Maitreya aroused bodhicitta in this way. The shepherd's way, called 'the arousing of bodhicitta beyond compare,' is the most courageous of all. It is said to be the way Lord Majur aroused bodhicitta."
article.heading: Ten grounds
article.paragraph: According to many traditions within Mahyna Buddhism, on the way to becoming a Buddha, a bodhisattva proceeds through ten, or sometimes fourteen, grounds orBhumi (Buddhism)bhmis.Below is the list of the tenbhmisand their descriptions according to theAvatamsaka SutraAvatasaka StraandThe Jewel Ornament of Liberation,a treatise byGampopa, an influential teacher of theTibetan BuddhismTibetanKagyuschool. (Other schools give slightly variant descriptions.)
Before a bodhisattva arrives at the first ground, he or she first must travel the first two of the five paths:

list.listitem: the path of accumulation
the path of preparation

article.paragraph: The ten grounds of the bodhisattva then can be grouped into the next three paths

list.listitem: bhmi1 the path of insight
bhmis2-7 the path of meditation
bhmis8-10 the path of no more learning

article.paragraph: The chapter of ten grounds in theAvatamsaka SutraAvatasaka Strarefers to 52 stages. The 10 grounds are:

list.listitem: Great Joy:It is said that being close to enlightenment and seeing the benefit for allSentient beings (Buddhism)sentient beings, one achieves great joy, hence the name. In thisbhmithe bodhisattvas practice allparamitaperfections(pramits), but especially emphasizingdana (Buddhism)generosity(dna).
Stainless:In accomplishing the secondbhmi, the bodhisattva is free from the stains of immorality, therefore, thisbhmiis named "stainless". The emphasized perfection isilamoral discipline(la).

Luminous:The thirdbhmiis named "luminous", because, for a bodhisattva who accomplishes thisbhmi, the light of Dharma is said to radiate for others from the bodhisattva. The emphasized perfection iskantipatience(IASTkṣānti).
Radiant:Thisbhmiis called "radiant", because it is said to be like a radiating light that fully burns that which opposes enlightenment. The emphasized perfection isvryavigor(vrya).

Very difficult to train:Bodhisattvas who attain thisbhmistrive to help sentient beings attain maturity, and do not become emotionally involved when such beings respond negatively, both of which are difficult to do. The emphasized perfection isDhyna in Buddhismmeditative concentration(dhyna).

Obviously Transcendent:By depending on the perfection of wisdom, [the bodhisattva] does not abide in eithersasraIASTsaṃsāraornirvaIASTnirvāṇa, so this state is "obviously transcendent". The emphasized perfection isWisdom in Buddhismwisdom(praj).
Gone afar:Particular emphasis is on the perfection ofupayaskillful means(upya), to help others.
Immovable:The emphasized virtue is aspiration. This, the "immovable"bhmi, is thebhmiat which one becomes able to choose his place of rebirth.
Good Discriminating Wisdom:The emphasized virtue is power.
Cloud of Dharma:The emphasized virtue is the practice of primordial wisdom.

article.paragraph: After the tenbhmis, according to Mahyna Buddhism, one attains complete enlightenment and becomes a Buddha.

With the 52 stages, theShurangama Sutraragama Strarecognizes 57 stages. With the 10 grounds, variousVajrayanaVajraynaschools recognize 310 additional grounds, mostly 6 more grounds with variant descriptions.cite webhttp://read.goodweb.cn/news/news_more.asp?lm2ԲϢ - Ŀ ļ21 August 2015cite webhttp://akanistha.blogspot.com/2009/08/blog-post_4818.html吉祥鄔金密嚴寺鄔金旺度21 August 2015
A bodhisattva above the 7th ground is called amahsattva. Some bodhisattvas such asSamantabhadraare also said to have already attained buddhahood.459
article.heading: School doctrines
article.paragraph: Some sutras said a beginner would take 322 countless eons (asakhyeyamahsakhyeyaKalpa (aeon)kalpas) to become a buddha..waybackhttp://aaa.org.tw/Chen_voice/a_2008_11_25.pdf20090411014117waybackhttp://www.hwayue.org.tw/lama/question4_08.htm20130526210637Pure Land Buddhismsuggests buddhists go to thepure landsto practice as bodhisattvas.Tiantai,Huayan schoolHuayan,ZenandVajrayanaVajraynaschools say they teach ways to attain buddhahood within one karmic cycle.cite webhttp://www.bukon.idv.tw/mantra/b11.htm顯教與密教21 August 2015

Various traditions within Buddhism believe in specific bodhisattvas. Some bodhisattvas appear across traditions, but due to language barriers may be seen as separate entities. For example,Tibetan BuddhismTibetan Buddhistsbelieve in various forms ofChenrezig, who isAvalokitesvaraAvalokitevarain Sanskrit,Guanyinin China, Gwan-eum in Korea, Quan Am in Vietnam, andKannonin Japan. Followers of Tibetan Buddhism consider theDalai Lamasand theKarmapasto be an emanation of Chenrezig, the Bodhisattva of Compassion.
KsitigarbhaKitigarbhais another popular bodhisattva in Japan and China. He is known for aiding those who are lost. His greatest compassionate vow is:

template.arg: If I do not go to the hell to help the suffering beings there, who else will go? ... if the hells are not empty I will not become a Buddha. Only when all living beings have been saved, will I attain Bodhi.

article.paragraph: The place of a bodhisattva's earthly deeds, such as the achievement ofenlightenment (Buddhism)enlightenmentor the acts ofDharma, is known as abodhimaa, and may be a site ofpilgrimage. Many temples and monasteries are famous as bodhimaas. Perhaps the most famous bodhimaa of all is theBodhi Treeunder whichShakyamunikyamuiachieved buddhahood. In the tradition ofChinese Buddhism, there are four mountains that are regarded as bodhimaas for bodhisattvas, with each site having major monasteries and being popular for pilgrimages by both monastics and laypeople. These four bodhimandas are:

list.listitem: PutuoshanMount Putuo: Avalokitevara Bodhisattva
Mount Emei:SamantabhadraBodhisattva
Mount Wutai:ManjusriMajurBodhisattva
Mount Jiuhua: Kitigarbha Bodhisattva
